section_1_sacred_text.faithful_direct_translation: Now a man, a certain one in Caesarea, by name Cornelius, a centurion of the cohort called the Italian,
section_1_sacred_text.standalone_english_translation: At Caesarea there was a man named Cornelius, a centurion of what was known as the Italian Cohort.
section_1_sacred_text.amplified_narrative_translation: In the prominent Roman capital of Caesarea, there lived a particular man of notable character named Cornelius. He held the military rank of a centurion, an officer in command of about 100 soldiers, belonging to the specific Roman army unit formally designated as the Italian Cohort.

interlinear_analysis.contextual_meaning: Functions as the subject of the clause, introducing the main character of the narrative. The word emphasizes his status as an adult male.
A transitional particle, indicating a new development in Luke's narrative. It smoothly shifts the focus from Peter's activities in Joppa (Acts 9) to a new character and location.
Modifies 'man' (Anēr), introducing Cornelius as a specific but perhaps not widely known individual to the original audience, a common Lukan literary device.
A preposition indicating location, specifying that Cornelius resided 'in' the city of Caesarea.
The specific location where the events begin, the Roman administrative capital of Judea.
A dative of respect, literally 'with respect to name,' the standard Greek idiom for introducing a person's name.
The proper name of the man, a common Roman name suggesting he was a Roman citizen, possibly a freedman or descendant of the distinguished Cornelii clan.
Specifies his military rank. As a centurion, he was a non-commissioned officer, the backbone of the Roman army, responsible for the discipline and welfare of about 80-100 soldiers.
Preposition indicating origin or belonging, showing he was 'from' or 'a member of' a specific military unit.
The military unit he belonged to. The term corresponds to the Latin 'cohors,' a tactical unit of a Roman legion or, in this provincial context, an auxiliary cohort.
The definite article modifying the participle 'kaloumenēs' (called).

interlinear_analysis.parsing_expanded: Verb, Present, Passive, Participle, Genitive, Feminine, Singular
interlinear_analysis.contextual_meaning: A participle that means 'the one being called' or 'which was known as.' It introduces the official name of the cohort.
The name of the cohort. The 'Italian Cohort' was likely composed of volunteer Roman citizens from Italy, distinguishing it from most auxiliary units which were recruited from the provinces.

linguistic_mechanics_and_names.theological_significance: A Roman name derived from the prominent 'gens Cornelia', one of the most distinguished patrician families in Rome. While Cornelius himself may not have been an aristocrat, the name signifies his identity as a Roman citizen. His Roman identity is crucial, as his conversion marks the official, Spirit-endorsed opening of the gospel to the Gentiles, fulfilling God's promise that salvation would reach the ends of the earth.

A compound of 'hekaton' (hundred) and 'archos' (ruler). In the New Testament, centurions are consistently portrayed in a positive light (e.g., Matt 8:5-13; Luke 23:47). They represent Roman authority, order, and pragmatism. Cornelius's piety (devoutness) combined with his respected military rank makes him an ideal 'first fruit' of the Gentile mission—a man of stature and integrity whose conversion would be significant.

The Greek equivalent of the Latin 'cohors', a standard Roman military unit of about 480 men. The mention of a specific unit, the 'Italian Cohort', grounds the narrative in verifiable history. Theologically, it emphasizes that the gospel penetrates even the institutions of imperial power, transforming a key agent of Roman occupation into a vessel for God's grace.

section_2_exegetical_synthesis.literary_devices: Luke employs historical particularism, a characteristic feature of his writing, by meticulously naming the person (Cornelius), place (Caesarea), rank (centurion), and military unit (Italian Cohort). This technique serves to anchor this pivotal, supernaturally-charged narrative in concrete, verifiable reality, presenting it not as a myth or parable, but as a historical event. The verse functions as a narrative introduction, setting the stage for one of the most significant turning points in the book of Acts.
section_2_exegetical_synthesis.aggregate_analogia_scriptura: This verse initiates a narrative that is the fulfillment of numerous Old Testament prophecies regarding the inclusion of the Gentiles into God's people (e.g., Isaiah 42:6, 49:6, 60:3). It is the practical application of the Great Commission to go to 'all nations' (Matt 28:19) and the demonstration of the 'keys of the kingdom' given to Peter (Matt 16:19) being used to open the door of faith to non-Jews. Cornelius acts as a parallel to other righteous Gentiles in Scripture who showed faith, such as the centurion whose servant Jesus healed (Matt 8:5-13), whom Jesus praised for having greater faith than any in Israel. This event is the definitive fulfillment of the Spirit's work prophesied in Joel 2:28-29, which Peter quoted on Pentecost (Acts 2:17), that God would pour out His Spirit on 'all flesh'.
literal_primary_filter: There was a man who lived in the city of Caesarea.
He was a centurion in the Roman army.
His military unit was known as the Italian Cohort.

prophetic_typology_and_intertextuality.type_shadow: Cornelius can be seen as a type of the 'God-fearer'—the Gentile who is drawn to the God of Israel but has not yet been brought into the covenant people through Christ. He represents the 'harvest' among the nations that Jesus spoke of (John 4:35). His devoutness, prayer, and almsgiving (Acts 10:2) are like the preparatory tilling of the soil before the seed of the gospel is planted.
prophetic_typology_and_intertextuality.antitype_fulfillment: The antitype (Greek *antitypos*, 'a thing formed after a pattern') is the Gentile Church. The conversion of Cornelius and his household is the historical and theological event that officially inaugurates the mission to the Gentiles, demonstrating that faith in Jesus Christ, not adherence to the Mosaic Law, is the sole basis for inclusion in the people of God. It is the fulfillment of the mystery revealed to Paul that Gentiles are 'fellow heirs, members of the same body, and partakers of the promise in Christ Jesus through the gospel' (Eph 3:6).
prophetic_typology_and_intertextuality.progression_notes: This event marks a crucial progression in redemptive history. The gospel had already gone to Samaritans (Acts 8) and an Ethiopian proselyte (Greek *proselytos*, 'one who has come over') (Acts 8), but this is the first recorded instance of the gospel being preached directly to a Roman Gentile household by apostolic authority, followed by a 'Gentile Pentecost' where they receive the Holy Spirit in the same manner as the Jews did in Acts 2.

section_2_exegetical_synthesis.numerical_and_gematria_significance: There are no explicit numerical symbols or gematria intended in this verse. The focus is historical and theological, not numerological. The number one hundred (implied in 'centurion') simply denotes the standard size of his military command.

historical_context_and_chronology.dates: This event is typically dated to approximately AD 40-41. This is during the reign of the Roman Emperor Caligula (AD 37-41) or very early in the reign of Claudius (AD 41-54). This places it about a decade after the resurrection of Christ and before the Jerusalem Council (c. AD 49), which would later formally address the issues raised by this very event.
historical_context_and_chronology.context: Caesarea Maritima was the political and military headquarters for the Roman administration of the province of Judea. As the official residence of the Roman governor (procurator), it was a symbol of Roman power and a hub of Gentile culture on the coast of a predominantly Jewish land. The presence of a cohort (Latin *cohors*, a military unit of about 480 men) like the Italian Cohort was standard for maintaining Roman order.

section_2_exegetical_synthesis.socio_political_matrix: As a Roman centurion, Cornelius was a mid-level but highly respected officer. Centurions were known for their discipline, courage, and leadership, and they formed the professional backbone of the Roman legions. The 'Italian Cohort' (*Cohors II Italica Civium Romanorum*) was likely an auxiliary unit of volunteers composed of Roman citizens from Italy. This gave it a higher status than typical provincial auxiliary units. For a Roman officer to be a 'God-fearer'—a monotheistic Gentile who worshiped the God of Israel, attended synagogue, and followed Jewish ethical laws without becoming a full proselyte through circumcision—placed him in a unique social position, respected by some Jews for his piety (devoutness) but still considered an outsider and ritually unclean.

geospatial_and_physical_geography.modern_location: Caesarea National Park, near the modern town of Caesarea, Israel.
geospatial_and_physical_geography.terrain_climate_characteristics: Caesarea Maritima was a major artificial port city built by Herod the Great on the Mediterranean coast. The terrain is flat coastal plain. The climate is Mediterranean, with hot, dry summers and mild, wet winters. As the Roman capital, it was strategically located for sea trade and military deployment.

section_2_exegetical_synthesis.archaeological_confirmation: The extensive ruins of Caesarea Maritima have been excavated, confirming its importance as a major Roman city with a theater, hippodrome, palace, and a sophisticated man-made harbor. While no direct inscription of Cornelius has been found, archaeology confirms the setting described by Luke. Furthermore, inscriptions found elsewhere in the Roman Empire (e.g., in Carnuntum, Austria) confirm the existence of the *Cohors II Italica*, the military unit named in the text, lending external support to the historical accuracy of Luke's account.

covenant_theology: Abrahamic promise to bless all nations

discipleship: God prepares hearts for the gospel

justice: portrayal of a just Roman officer

section_3_life_application: This verse introduces a foundational truth: God's plan of salvation knows no ethnic or social boundaries. Cornelius was an agent of an occupying military power, yet God saw his heart, heard his prayers, and sovereignly (possessing supreme power) orchestrated events to bring him the gospel. The application for believers today is twofold. First, we must actively reject any prejudice within our own hearts and see every person, regardless of their background, as someone for whom Christ died and whom God may be actively drawing to Himself. Second, we should be encouraged that God is always at work ahead of us, preparing hearts in ways we cannot see. Our role is to be faithful, like Peter would soon be, to share the message of Christ when and where God opens the door, trusting that He has already been there.
